page.title: 15A FERNESS GAMEKEEPER'S YEAR
page.content: A gamekeeper is concerned with fishing, shooting (mainly grouse and pheasants but also duck, woodcock and pigeon) and stalking (mainly roe deer- bucks in summer, does in winter). Vermin control is done throughout the year, terriers being used to flush foxes from burrows, and ferrets for rabbits. Grouse shooting begins on the 'glorious' 12th of August and costs about Â£10 per brace. In spring and autumn heather is burnt in strips to provide better feeding and cover for the grouse. Pheasants are shot in winter but chicks have to be hatched and reared in spring and summer for release and fed daily over the winter. Various breeds of dogs are used in stalking. Scrub clearance along river banks helps maintain fishing beats.
